Craig Lord Global News Posted May 21, 2020 12:31 pm Updated May 21, 2020 11:29 pm 2:48 Some Shopify employees will work from home permanently: CEO WATCH: Shopify's CEO announced Thursday most employees won‚Äôt return to the office after the pandemic and instead will be working remotely. Erica Vella has details. comments Leave a comment facebook Share this item on Facebook whatsapp Share this item via WhatsApp twitter Share this item on Twitter email Send this page to someone via email more Share this item more Share this item Smaller font Descrease article font size -A Larger font Increase article font size A+ Share this item on Facebook facebook Share this item via WhatsApp whatsapp Share this item on Twitter twitter Send this page to someone via email email Share this item on Pinterest pinterest Share this item on LinkedIn linkedin Share this item on Reddit reddit Copy article link Copy link Employees at Shopify will continue to work from home even after the novel coronavirus pandemic ends, the booming Canadian tech giant announced Thursday. The e-commerce platform developer, headquartered in Ottawa with more than 5,000 employees in Toronto, Waterloo, Montreal, Vancouver and around the world, will keep its offices closed until the end of 2021 to prepare for the company‚Äôs permanent work-for-home reality, CEO Tobi Lutke tweeted Thursday morning. When those offices do reopen, most employees will continue to work from home. ‚ÄúShopify is a digital by default company,‚Äù Lutke tweeted. ‚ÄúOffice centricity is over.‚Äù 5:01 Coronavirus and the workplace Coronavirus and the workplace Shopify, which surpassed more than 1,000 employees in its hometown of Ottawa last year and briefly overtook RBC as Canada‚Äôs most valuable company on the Toronto Stock Exchange a few weeks ago, was an early adopter of remote working amid the coronavirus pandemic. Story continues below advertisement The company asked its entire staff to work from home starting March 11, with Lutke noting then that a large portion of the company‚Äôs workforce already worked remotely. Lutke said in his tweets Thursday that every Shopify employee will now have the same experience no matter where they work. READ MORE: Working from home because of coronavirus? Here‚Äôs how to stay productive He noted it will also help the company connect to the merchants it serves, as many direct-to-consumer businesses that use the Shopify platform to power their online stores also work from home. Lutke said Shopify hasn‚Äôt figured out all the details yet around operating a remote-first business but that the company has always been good at change. COVID is challenging us all to work together in new ways. We choose to jump in the driver‚Äôs seat, instead of being passengers to the changes ahead. We cannot go back to the way things were. This isn‚Äôt a choice; this is the future ‚Äî Tobi Lutke üå≥üå≤üõíüïπ (@tobi) May 21, 2020 Story continues below advertisement Shawn Hamilton, a senior vice-president with real estate services firm CBRE in Ottawa, tells Global News that the local e-commerce giant has long been a trendsetter in the city‚Äôs office market, and if anyone can make a leap like this work, it‚Äôs Shopify. Trending Stories Nurse struggling with COVID-19 trauma found dead in his car Dollar fight? Loon killed bald eagle with ‚Äòshot through the heart‚Äô ‚ÄúIf it were any other company I would take it as a venting of frustration. But these guys have always been the thin edge of the wedge in leading the way,‚Äù Hamilton says. The technology to enable a fully remote operation is already in place, Hamilton says, but what will make or break Shopify‚Äôs remote experiment is the sociological dimensions of working in an office and meeting others face to face. In other words, the coronavirus pandemic has proven tech companies can work from home ‚Äî now they have to decide if they really want to. Lutke‚Äôs decision to have employees permanently work remotely comes after Shopify started beefing up its real estate with a new office in Toronto at the King Portland Centre, steps away from the company‚Äôs first office in Canada‚Äôs largest city. It also announced that it would lease about 23,597 square metres (253,995 square feet) of space at The Well complex in Toronto to be built at Front Street West and Spadina Avenue. In January, the company said it would open its first permanent office in downtown Vancouver at the Four Bentall Centre by late 2020. Story continues below advertisement READ MORE: Burnout is real ‚Äî even when working from home And back in Ottawa, Shopify operates from its 150 Elgin St. headquarters with another office around the corner at 234 Laurier Ave. But what will happen to these offices if Shopify no longer needs to fill them with employees? In a statement to Global News, a Shopify spokesperson said the company will be ‚Äúre-designing‚Äù its existing offices and is ‚Äúcommitted to retaining recruitment hubs‚Äù in its major Canadian markets. Should Shopify opt to downsize any of its offices in downtown Ottawa, Hamilton believes there will be sufficient demand to snap up any vacant space. New private-sector players with a ‚Äúdifferent philosophy‚Äù on office space might take over a few floors from the e-commerce firm, or the federal government, which was already growing in size before the pandemic hit, could swoop in to boost its own downtown portfolio, he suggests. While Shopify has been a trendsetter for years to other urban tech companies in Ottawa, Hamilton suggests other startups tread carefully before tearing up their leases. ‚ÄúI would caution companies to make changes, not borne out of frustration, but because it is a strategic, measured complement to their business,‚Äù he says. Shopify‚Äôs latest news comes just a day after it unveiled a slew of new products to support merchants through the COVID-19 pandemic during its online Reunite conference. Story continues below advertisement The company‚Äôs stock now regularly reaches more than $1,000 in trading, and the company says more than one million businesses now use its offerings. ‚Äî With files from Canadian Press 3:05 Shopify continues to grow amid Toronto‚Äôs evolving tech scene Shopify continues to grow amid Toronto‚Äôs evolving tech scene ¬© 2020 Global News, a division of Corus Entertainment Inc. Rod Phillips said the pandemic has created an ‚Äúunprecedented health crisis‚Äù and the province had to spend billions to support the health-care sector and help businesses and residents weather the storm. In March, the Progressive Conservative government said the deficit would reach $20.5 billion by the end of 2020-2021, but Phillips said Wednesday that due to billions more in spending required by the ongoing pandemic, the number is set to reach $38.5 billion. Read more: Canada‚Äôs deficit ‚Äòmanageable‚Äô without tax increase if COVID-19 measures temporary: PBO ‚ÄúWe remain in uncertain times and the risk of a second wave is real despite our collective efforts to avert it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe economic impacts of COVID-19 globally, and in Ontario, are still unfolding.‚Äù Story continues below advertisement In its spring fiscal update, the province announced a $17-billion spending package designed to provide aid during the pandemic. The government said Wednesday that its COVID-19 relief spending will now total $30 billion by the close of the fiscal year. Overall, the government expects to spend an additional $13 billion on programs this year, while collecting $5.7 billion less in taxes and other revenues because of the pandemic. Among the new measures announced in Wednesday‚Äôs update, the province now plans to add $4.3 billion more to a health-care spending contingency fund in advance of a potential second wave of coronavirus cases this fall. 2:20 Ontario‚Äôs deficit balloons to $38.5B amid ongoing coronavirus pandemic Ontario‚Äôs deficit balloons to $38.5B amid ongoing coronavirus pandemic Toronto to receive $404M in emergency coronavirus pandemic transit funding Coronavirus: Parents create mock classroom to protest Ontario‚Äôs back-to-school plan Coronavirus: 2 City of Toronto camps suspended after positive test Coronavirus: Ford government projects budget deficit will jump to $38.5B in 2020-21 Coronavirus: Ontario pledges $1.6B for municipalities, including funding for transit Previous Video Next Video The ‚ÄúSafe Restart Agreement‚Äù the provinces recently reached with the federal government will cost Ontario $2.4 billion, while another $2.2 billion will be added to a standard contingency fund. Story continues below advertisement The cost to Ontario for the promised pandemic pay for front-line workers is estimated at $1.1 billion. Prior to the pandemic, Ontario had been projecting a $9-billion deficit for 2020-2021 and Premier Doug Ford had pledged to balance the province‚Äôs books by 2023-2024 ‚Äî into a hypothetical second mandate for the Tories. Phillips stressed that the government had been on track to achieve that goal, but COVID-19 required immediate action. ‚ÄúWhile the current level of government spending and deficits are not sustainable over the long term, they are necessary today,‚Äù he said. Story continues below advertisement The premier also defended the spending and acknowledged that balancing the budget by 2023 was no longer possible. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to be very frank,‚Äù Ford said Wednesday. ‚ÄúIt was a whole different situation six months ago compared to now. But we‚Äôre going to continue to be very fiscally conservative (and) responsible.‚Äù Ford has said repeatedly since the start of the pandemic that the province would not hold back spending if it felt it could save lives. Now, he said, it‚Äôs about ensuring people clearly understand how the money is being spent. ‚ÄúI kept my promise to the people of Ontario,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhen this first started, I said ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄòI‚Äôm not going to spare a penny,‚Äô and I‚Äôve proved it.‚Äù 2:06 Financial watchdog estimates Ontario could face $41B deficit Financial watchdog estimates Ontario could face $41B deficit The premier‚Äôs spending plan received a vote of confidence from the Canadian Union of Public Employees, which said in a statement that the higher deficit ‚Äúshould not be cause for concern.‚Äù Story continues below advertisement ‚ÄúWe need more investment and support to help Ontario continue to manage and to rebound out of this crisis,‚Äù the union‚Äôs Ontario president, Fred Hahn, said. ‚ÄúBecause spending saves lives. What the pandemic has taught us is that we need more collective resources, not less.‚Äù NDP finance critic Sandy Shaw noted that the fiscal update shows the government has spent just $218 million on long-term care since April. ‚ÄúMore than 1,845 seniors and front-line health care workers tragically died in long-term care homes,‚Äù Shaw said in a statement. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs abundantly, heart-breakingly clear that $218 million was nowhere near enough to fund the iron ring around nursing homes that was needed.‚Äù Earlier this year, the province postponed its annual budget, which is normally introduced in March. The government said it will instead introduce its full spending package on or before Nov. 14.
